name: Formal Proof Methods
description: Mastering the different proof techniques used in mathematics and logic.

cards.title: Direct Proofs & Logical Deduction
cards.description: Learning how to construct step-by-step logical arguments.
bulletpoints: A direct proof shows that \( P \Rightarrow Q \) by assuming \( P \) and deriving \( Q \)
Example: Prove that if \( n \) is even, then \( n^2 \) is even: \[ n = 2k \Rightarrow n^2 = 4k^2 = 2(2k^2) \]
Apply direct proofs in number theory, inequalities, and algebra.
cards.summaryText: Assume the hypothesis and derive the conclusion through linear logical steps across algebraic domains.

cards.title: Indirect Proofs: Contradiction & Contraposition
cards.description: Using indirect reasoning to establish the truth of mathematical statements.
bulletpoints: Proof by contraposition: To prove \( P \Rightarrow Q \), prove \( \neg Q \Rightarrow \neg P \)
Proof by contradiction assumes \( \neg P \) and derives a contradiction: \[ P \Rightarrow (Q \land \neg Q) \Rightarrow \text{False} \]
Example: Prove \( \sqrt{2} \) is irrational by contradiction.
cards.summaryText: Establish results via contraposition or by negating the claim and deriving an impossibility.

cards.title: Mathematical Induction & Recursive Proofs
cards.description: Using induction to prove statements about sequences and structures.
bulletpoints: Mathematical induction consists of two steps: \[ \text{Base Case: Prove } P(1). \] \[ \text{Inductive Step: Assume } P(k) \text{ and prove } P(k+1). \]
Example: Prove \( 1 + 2 + ... + n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \) using induction.
Strong induction applies when the inductive step depends on multiple prior cases.
cards.summaryText: Verify the base case and push statements forward with standard or strong inductive steps.

cards.title: Proof by Contradiction & Paradoxes
cards.description: Examining famous contradictions and logical paradoxes.
bulletpoints: Understand the principle of reductio ad absurdum, proving \( P \) by showing \( \neg P \) leads to a contradiction.
Explore Russell’s paradox in naive set theory: \[ R = \{ x \mid x \notin x \} \Rightarrow R \in R \iff R \notin R \]
Apply contradiction proofs to irrational numbers and prime theorems.
cards.summaryText: Assume the negation to expose contradictions, illuminating paradoxes and classical impossibility proofs.

cards.title: Proofs in Set Theory & Cardinality
cards.description: Using logical methods to establish properties of sets and cardinality.
bulletpoints: Prove set identities using the subset method: \[ A \subseteq B \text{ and } B \subseteq A \Rightarrow A = B \]
Establish the uncountability of \( \mathbb{R} \) using Cantor’s diagonal argument.
Apply proof techniques to power sets, unions, and intersections.
cards.summaryText: Leverage subset arguments and diagonalization to prove core set-theoretic identities and sizes.

cards.title: Epsilon-Delta Proofs in Analysis
cards.description: Constructing rigorous proofs of limits and continuity.
bulletpoints: Prove that \( \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L \) using the definition: \[ \forall \epsilon > 0, \exists \delta > 0 \text{ such that } |x - a| < \delta \Rightarrow |f(x) - L| < \epsilon. \]
Use epsilon-delta arguments to prove function continuity and differentiability.
Apply these methods to sequences, functions, and real analysis.
cards.summaryText: Deploy epsilon–delta bounds to rigorously confirm limits, continuity, and analytic properties.

cards.title: Proofs in Number Theory
cards.description: Exploring classic number theory proofs and divisibility rules.
bulletpoints: Prove the infinitude of primes using contradiction: \[ \prod_{i=1}^{n} p_i + 1 \text{ is prime or has a new prime factor.} \]
Prove modular arithmetic properties: \[ a \equiv b \pmod{m} \Rightarrow a^k \equiv b^k \pmod{m}. \]
Use Diophantine equation proofs in integer solutions.
cards.summaryText: Apply contradiction, modular arithmetic, and Diophantine techniques to classic number theory statements.

cards.title: Proofs in Graph Theory
cards.description: Applying formal proof methods to properties of graphs and networks.
bulletpoints: Use induction to prove properties of trees: \[ |V| - |E| = 1 \text{ for connected acyclic graphs.} \]
Apply contradiction to show that a graph with odd-degree vertices has an Eulerian path.
Use planarity proofs and coloring theorems.
cards.summaryText: Combine induction, contradiction, and structural reasoning to prove graph properties and traversals.

cards.title: Proofs in Group Theory
cards.description: Constructing rigorous proofs in abstract algebra.
bulletpoints: Prove that a group of prime order is cyclic: \[ |G| = p \Rightarrow G \text{ is cyclic.} \]
Use Lagrange’s theorem: \[ |H| \text{ divides } |G| \text{ for any finite group } G. \]
Apply homomorphism and isomorphism theorems.
cards.summaryText: Invoke group order arguments and structure theorems to demonstrate fundamental algebraic facts.

cards.title: Axiomatic Proofs & First-Order Logic
cards.description: Using formal axiomatic systems to construct rigorous proofs.
bulletpoints: Study Peano’s axioms and the foundations of number theory.
Use Hilbert’s formalism to derive theorems in logic.
Understand Gödel’s incompleteness theorem: \[ \text{Any consistent formal system } S \text{ contains true statements that cannot be proven.} \]
cards.summaryText: Employ axiomatic systems like Peano, Hilbert, and Gödel to ground formal logical reasoning.
